feed.title: Category: OpenMP | A Coding Monkey's Blog

entry.title: Iterative closest points(ICP) demo
entry.content:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=igb8mAJ6F5I

The Perl code generating the plot is listed below

```perl

!/usr/bin/perl

use strict; use warnings; use Chart::Gnuplot;

Write running time

open my $IN, '<', "benchmark.dat" or die $!;

Data

my @x; my @y;

while( <$IN> ) {

chomp;
my ($t1, $t2) = split /\s/;
push @x, $t1;
push @y, $t2;

}

Create chart object and specify the properties of the chart

my $chart = Chart::Gnuplot->new(

output => "out.eps",
title  => "Iterative Closest Points with Stanford Bunny",
xlabel => "Number of threads",
ylabel => "Time(s)",
boxwidth => "0.8 relative"

);

Create dataset object and specify the properties of the dataset

my $dataSet = Chart::Gnuplot::DataSet->new(

xdata => \@x,
ydata => \@y,
title => "Time",
#style => "linespoints",
style => "boxes",
fill => "0.75",

);

Plot the data set on the chart

$chart->plot2d($dataSet);

#

Plot many data sets on a single chart

$chart->plot2d($dataSet1, $dataSet2, ...);

```

entry.title: Using OpenMP with CMake
entry.content:
Add the following lines into your CMakeLists.txt

# Even though -fopenmp won't appear in the GUI options, it does take effect
SET(CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS "${CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS} -fopenmp")
SET(CMAKE_C_FLAGS "${CMAKE_C_FLAGS} -fopenmp")
